column4: You said that this system would run entirely in RAM. If you can be sure that there will never be any filesystems mounted you can halt directly, without going through the normal shutdown process.
yes, that's exactly what I want to do. But how do I bind that action to the power button???
I see two possible goals, 1: Avoid the normal user prompt 2: Avoid the usual shutdown uglyness. Do you care about both or just the latter?
2 is the most important. 1 I can solve via the Ubuntu power preferences, so it's not really a problem
also, I want to make certain the box is actually shutoff. I don't want to come back after a 3 week holiday and find it's been hanging on something stupid like alsa-mixer-save (which can happen...)
I want to say you should put a script in /etc/rc0.d/ but there is probably a better, upstart oriented, way to do it.

yeah, and I tried a K00 script in /etc/rc0.d, but still get the messages. Surely there's SOMEONE who actually knows how Ubuntu 10.04 works...? I can't find anything to fix this on the internet. Tried /usr/lib/hal/scripts/*, /etc/acpi/*, /etc/acpi/events/* /etc/rc0.d/* and nothing actually does it
What was in the script?
#!/bin/sh; poweroff -f
echo o | /proc/sysrq-trigger
just about tried it without thinking, then realized what it was ;-)
I know that poweroff -f works tho, so the actual command itself isn't an issue
but I'll try it anyway
Ahh, you need update-rc.d.
ok, what does that do?
I'm still researching. You might want to ask in #upstart
